elements.content: It is an urgent topic for public health and environmental protection to remove Cr­(VI) from wastewater effectively and conveniently. Herein, we fabricate the novel hybrid magnetic material HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 (HPU-13 = {[Cu3(L)2]·OH·2CH3CH2OH·10H2O} n ; HL = 2-(5-pyridin-4-yl-2H-[1,2,4]­triazol-3-yl)­pyrimidine), which shows excellent Cr­(VI) removal efficiency and is easily employed as a reusable absorbent. The maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– adsorbed on HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 were 398.41 and 471.69 mg/g, respectively, larger than those of reported MOFs used in Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– adsorption. Adsorption mechanism studies confirmed that the synergistic reaction of Cr­(VI) reduction and adsorption was responsible for the high removal efficiency. The above evidence proved that HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 has the potential functional ability to decontaminate Cr­(VI) polluted water systems.
elements.clean_text: It is an urgent topic for public health and environmental protection to remove Cr(VI) from wastewater effectively and conveniently. Herein, we fabricate the novel hybrid magnetic material HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  (HPU-13 = {[Cu3(L)2]⋅OH⋅2CH3CH2OH⋅10H2O} n ; HL = 2-(5-pyridin-4-yl-2H-[1,2,4]triazol-3-yl)pyrimidine), which shows excellent Cr(VI) removal efficiency and is easily employed as a reusable absorbent. The maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- adsorbed on HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  were 398.41 and 471.69 mg/g, respectively, larger than those of reported MOFs used in Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- adsorption. Adsorption mechanism studies confirmed that the synergistic reaction of Cr(VI) reduction and adsorption was responsible for the high removal efficiency. The above evidence proved that HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  has the potential functional ability to decontaminate Cr(VI) polluted water systems.

elements.content: A stable and recoverable hybrid magnetic material with hierarchically engineered micropores shows remarkable adsorption capability toward Cr­(VI) removal through the synergistic reaction of Cr­(VI) reduction and adsorption.
elements.clean_text: A stable and recoverable hybrid magnetic material with hierarchically engineered micropores shows remarkable adsorption capability toward Cr(VI) removal through the synergistic reaction of Cr(VI) reduction and adsorption.

elements.content: With the rapid development of industry, heavy-metal pollution has been considered as a severe environmental pollution issue to be addressed because of its poor degradability, biologically related toxicity, and easy accumulation. In particular, Cr­(VI) is greatly carcinogenic, mutagenic, and genotoxic to humans. Accordingly, various techniques applied in removing Cr­(VI) such as adsorption, ion exchange, reduction, and precipitation have been reported to effectively purify Cr­(VI)-contaminated water. Among the different purification methods, the synergistic reaction of Cr­(VI) reduction and adsorption is an attractive approach to remove Cr­(VI) pollutants, which has the advantages of easy operation, high efficiency, and favorable ability to reduce the toxicity of Cr­(VI)-polluted water by the reduction of Cr­(VI) to Cr­(III). However, the use of some common modified zeolites, activated carbon, sawdust, chitosan, and nanoadsorbents cannot always be completely satisfactory for the aforementioned integrated approach because of their inherent drawbacks such as low functionality and characteristics, which obstruct their further development and application. Thus, exploring newly synthesized materials with large adsorption capacity, affinity, and reactivity for Cr­(VI) is particularly important.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

With the rapid development of industry, heavy-metal pollution has been considered as a severe environmental pollution issue to be addressed because of its poor degradability, biologically related toxicity, and easy accumulation. In particular, Cr(VI) is greatly carcinogenic, mutagenic, and genotoxic to humans. Accordingly, various techniques applied in removing Cr(VI) such as adsorption, ion exchange, reduction, and precipitation have been reported to effectively purify Cr(VI)-contaminated water. Among the different purification methods, the synergistic reaction of Cr(VI) reduction and adsorption is an attractive approach to remove Cr(VI) pollutants, which has the advantages of easy operation, high efficiency, and favorable ability to reduce the toxicity of Cr(VI)-polluted water by the reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III). However, the use of some common modified zeolites, activated carbon, sawdust, chitosan, and nanoadsorbents cannot always be completely satisfactory for the aforementioned integrated approach because of their inherent drawbacks such as low functionality and characteristics, which obstruct their further development and application. Thus, exploring newly synthesized materials with large adsorption capacity, affinity, and reactivity for Cr(VI) is particularly important.

elements.content: As a new kind of porous material, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) possess the favorable advantages of adjusting the properties of the pore surface and channel size, which would facilitate the synergistic reaction of Cr­(VI) reduction, size-confinement effects, adsorption, and ion exchange. However, powdered MOFs have defects that make them difficult to separate from water, which restrict their practical application. With these criteria in mind, embedding ferrites into conducting MOFs to construct a hybrid material is expected to be an effective approach, as it is easy to achieve separation of this material from water under the influence of an external magnet and the water stability also can be enhanced moderately. Thus, we report a stable and recoverable magnetic hybrid material that shows a remarkable adsorption capability for Cr­(VI) and elucidate the synergistic reaction of Cr­(VI) reduction and adsorption to accomplish high removal efficiency (). Moreover, the effects of different experimental parameters such as initial Cr­(VI) concentration, competing ions, and contact time are also investigated on Cr­(VI) adsorption. Large adsorption capacity and an excellent reusability estimate make the hybrid material a highly effective adsorbent for Cr­(VI).
elements.clean_text: As a new kind of porous material, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) possess the favorable advantages of adjusting the properties of the pore surface and channel size, which would facilitate the synergistic reaction of Cr(VI) reduction, size-confinement effects, adsorption, and ion exchange. However, powdered MOFs have defects that make them difficult to separate from water, which restrict their practical application. With these criteria in mind, embedding ferrites into conducting MOFs to construct a hybrid material is expected to be an effective approach, as it is easy to achieve separation of this material from water under the influence of an external magnet and the water stability also can be enhanced moderately. Thus, we report a stable and recoverable magnetic hybrid material that shows a remarkable adsorption capability for Cr(VI) and elucidate the synergistic reaction of Cr(VI) reduction and adsorption to accomplish high removal efficiency (). Moreover, the effects of different experimental parameters such as initial Cr(VI) concentration, competing ions, and contact time are also investigated on Cr(VI) adsorption. Large adsorption capacity and an excellent reusability estimate make the hybrid material a highly effective adsorbent for Cr(VI).

elements.content: All chemical reagents were available commercially and were used as purchased. IR data were collected on a Bruker TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer as KBr pellets in the region of 400–4500 cm–1. A Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer was used for elemental analyses (C, H, and N). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were examined by a PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. A Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in the atmosphere was used for Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. The UV spectra were characterized by a Purkinje General TU-1800 spectrophotometer. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM; S-4800, Hitachi, Japan) was introduced to characterize the microstructures and morphologies of the materials. The surface elements of the materials were characterized by electron dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). A Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) system was employed to obtain XPS spectra (an Al K X-ray source was used).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All chemical reagents were available commercially and were used as purchased. IR data were collected on a Bruker TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer as KBr pellets in the region of 400-4500 cm-1. A Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer was used for elemental analyses (C, H, and N). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were examined by a PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. A Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in the atmosphere was used for Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in the temperature range of 30-800 °C. The UV spectra were characterized by a Purkinje General TU-1800 spectrophotometer. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM; S-4800, Hitachi, Japan) was introduced to characterize the microstructures and morphologies of the materials. The surface elements of the materials were characterized by electron dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). A Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) system was employed to obtain XPS spectra (an Al K X-ray source was used).

elements.content: A mixture of CuSO4 (24.9 mg) and HL (11 mg) in H2O and ethanol (8/2) was placed in a 15 mL bottle and heated for 72 h at 160 °C. The final solution was cooled to room temperature, and then yellow block crystals of HPU-13 were acquired, washed with acetone, and dried in air. Yield: 78%. Anal. Calcd for C26H47Cu3N12O13: C, 33.71; H, 5.11; N, 18.14. Found: C, 33.64; H, 5.16; N, 18.22.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Cu3(L)2]⋅OH⋅2CH3CH2OH⋅10H2O} n  (HPU-13)

A mixture of CuSO4 (24.9 mg) and HL (11 mg) in H2O and ethanol (8/2) was placed in a 15 mL bottle and heated for 72 h at 160 °C. The final solution was cooled to room temperature, and then yellow block crystals of HPU-13 were acquired, washed with acetone, and dried in air. Yield: 78%. Anal. Calcd for C26H47Cu3N12O13: C, 33.71; H, 5.11; N, 18.14. Found: C, 33.64; H, 5.16; N, 18.22.

elements.content:
The Fe3O4 particles were prepared according to the literature.

Synthesis of Magnetic <bold>HPU-13@Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> </bold> particles

A mixture of CuSO4 (24.9 mg) and HL (11 mg) in H2O and ethanol (8/2) was first stirred for 30 min. Then, to the solution was added 2 mg of Fe3O4, and this mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon liner and heated to 160 °C for 72 h. The final product was centrifuged and washed several times with fresh water.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Fe3O4 Particles

The Fe3O4 particles were prepared according to the literature. 

Synthesis of Magnetic HPU-13@Fe3O4  particles

A mixture of CuSO4 (24.9 mg) and HL (11 mg) in H2O and ethanol (8/2) was first stirred for 30 min. Then, to the solution was added 2 mg of Fe3O4, and this mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon liner and heated to 160 °C for 72 h. The final product was centrifuged and washed several times with fresh water.

elements.content: An aqueous solution of Cr2O7 2–, CrO4 2–, or dye was obtained by dissolving K2Cr2O7, K2CrO4, or dye in deionized water. An equal amount of adsorbent (30 mg) was added to 10 mL of Cr2O7 2– or CrO4 2– (50, 100, 200, 300, 400, 500 ppm) or dye (20, 50, 100, 200, 300, 400 ppm) in each adsorption experiment. The absorbance of UV spectra was used to determine the Cr2O7 2–, CrO4 2–, and dye concentration. The uptake (%) was calculated on the basis of the formula q e = ( C 0 − C e ) V m × 100 % where q e (mg/g) stands for the amount of Cr2O7 2–, CrO4 2–, or dye adsorbed per gram of absorbents at equilibrium, C 0 and C e represent the initial and residual concentrations, respectively (mg/L), and V and m are the solution volume (mL) and the mass of the adsorbent, respectively. The solution was placed in a constant-temperature shaker (SHA-C, Guohua) at a speed of 150 rpm. A 100 μL portion of the solution was picked out during the shaking period, diluted to 2 mL, and evaluated by UV absorbance.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Experiment, Sorption Kinetics, and Sorption Isotherm

An aqueous solution of Cr2O7 2-, CrO4 2-, or dye was obtained by dissolving K2Cr2O7, K2CrO4, or dye in deionized water. An equal amount of adsorbent (30 mg) was added to 10 mL of Cr2O7 2- or CrO4 2- (50, 100, 200, 300, 400, 500 ppm) or dye (20, 50, 100, 200, 300, 400 ppm) in each adsorption experiment. The absorbance of UV spectra was used to determine the Cr2O7 2-, CrO4 2-, and dye concentration. The uptake (%) was calculated on the basis of the formula      q   e   =    (   C   0   -   C   e   )  V   m   × 100 %   where q e (mg/g) stands for the amount of Cr2O7 2-, CrO4 2-, or dye adsorbed per gram of absorbents at equilibrium, C 0 and C e represent the initial and residual concentrations, respectively (mg/L), and V and m are the solution volume (mL) and the mass of the adsorbent, respectively. The solution was placed in a constant-temperature shaker (SHA-C, Guohua) at a speed of 150 rpm. A 100 μL portion of the solution was picked out during the shaking period, diluted to 2 mL, and evaluated by UV absorbance.

elements.content: The effects of competing ions were carried out under the disturbance of the most familiar competing anions: i.e., F–, NO3 –, SO4 2–, Cl–, H2PO4 –, and Br– (3-fold molar, 6-fold molar, 9-fold molar, and 12-fold molar). Recoverability experiments were accomplished by soaking the Cr­(VI)-loaded material in NaNO3-saturated aqueous solution for 2 h.
elements.clean_text:
Effects of the Competing Ions and Recoverability of Material

The effects of competing ions were carried out under the disturbance of the most familiar competing anions: i.e., F-, NO3 -, SO4 2-, Cl-, H2PO4 -, and Br- (3-fold molar, 6-fold molar, 9-fold molar, and 12-fold molar). Recoverability experiments were accomplished by soaking the Cr(VI)-loaded material in NaNO3-saturated aqueous solution for 2 h.

elements.content: The crystallographic diffraction data for HPU-13 were collected by using a Siemens Smart CCD single-crystal X-ray diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ= 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Direct methods using the SHELXS-2014 program of the SHELXTL package was employed to handle the structure, which was then refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with SHELXL-2014. The SADABS program was used to correct all empirical absorption. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms in the crystal structure. The crystallographic data and structural refinement parameters of HPU-13 are presented in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

The crystallographic diffraction data for HPU-13 were collected by using a Siemens Smart CCD single-crystal X-ray diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ= 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Direct methods using the SHELXS-2014 program of the SHELXTL package was employed to handle the structure, which was then refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with SHELXL-2014. The SADABS program was used to correct all empirical absorption. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms in the crystal structure. The crystallographic data and structural refinement parameters of HPU-13 are presented in Table S1.

elements.content: HPU-13 crystallizes in the rrigonal system with space group P3̅c1, which is clearly indicated by single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis. It consists of hexagonal and triangular cationic micropores with a three-dimensional crystallographically imposed molecular symmetry. As depicted in a, the ligand has a μ4-bridging mode with each of the ligand’s six nitrogen atoms linking with four Cu­(I) ions by all of the nitrogen atoms. The two crystallographically independent Cu­(I) atoms possess distorted-tetrahedral geometries. Three independent ligands bridge six Cu­(I) atoms to form a closed triangular unit, which link with another triangular unit in a face-to-face direction, giving rise to a closed cage (b,c). Four adjacent triangular cages are connected together to form a hexagonal mesropore. An investigation of the crystal packing indicates that HPU-13 shows a porous structural character with two different channels: hexagonal and triangular micropores along the c axis due to the existence of the skeletons of ligands. The hexagonal cage has large dimensions of 20.947 × 20.720 Å2 (d,e). The triangular micropores have a pore size of 4 Å from the nitrogen atoms of HL groups. Finally, the whole structure might appear as an expansion of the MIL-68 structure (f). The effective free voids of HPU-13 are occupied as 36.0% of the crystal volume, which was calculated by PLATON analysis (1728.9 out of 4803.0 Å3, the unit cell volume).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description

 HPU-13 crystallizes in the rrigonal system with space group P3̅c1, which is clearly indicated by single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis. It consists of hexagonal and triangular cationic micropores with a three-dimensional crystallographically imposed molecular symmetry. As depicted in a, the ligand has a μ4-bridging mode with each of the ligand's six nitrogen atoms linking with four Cu(I) ions by all of the nitrogen atoms. The two crystallographically independent Cu(I) atoms possess distorted-tetrahedral geometries. Three independent ligands bridge six Cu(I) atoms to form a closed triangular unit, which link with another triangular unit in a face-to-face direction, giving rise to a closed cage (b,c). Four adjacent triangular cages are connected together to form a hexagonal mesropore. An investigation of the crystal packing indicates that HPU-13 shows a porous structural character with two different channels: hexagonal and triangular micropores along the c axis due to the existence of the skeletons of ligands. The hexagonal cage has large dimensions of 20.947 × 20.720 Å2 (d,e). The triangular micropores have a pore size of 4 Å from the nitrogen atoms of HL groups. Finally, the whole structure might appear as an expansion of the MIL-68 structure (f). The effective free voids of HPU-13 are occupied as 36.0% of the crystal volume, which was calculated by PLATON analysis (1728.9 out of 4803.0 Å3, the unit cell volume).

elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environments of Cu1 and Cu2 in HPU-13. (b) Closed triangular unit. (c) Closed cage. (d) Hexagonal mesopores and triangular micropores. (e) the hexagonal cage; (f) the three-dimensional porous framework.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) View of the coordination environments of Cu1 and Cu2 in HPU-13. (b) Closed triangular unit. (c) Closed cage. (d) Hexagonal mesopores and triangular micropores. (e) the hexagonal cage; (f) the three-dimensional porous framework.

elements.content: The eco-friendliness and thermal and water stability of materials are requisites for applications. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) were used to inspect the thermal stability of HPU-13 (Figure S1a,b). The TGA analysis shows that HPU-13 loses weight from 70 to 102 °C, ascribed to the free CH3CH2OH and H2O molecules (calcd 19.4% H2O and 9.9% CH3CH2OH), and the framework starts to collapse at 378 °C. The PXRD of synthesized HPU-13, which is similar to the simulated result from the single-crystal data, reveals the purity of HPU-13. In addition, the PXRD patterns of a fresh sample of HPU-13 in H2O for 72 h also matches well with that of the original synthesized product, proving that this material has a good resistance to H2O. Therefore, such H2O stability makes HPU-13 more feasible in practical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Water Stability Tests

The eco-friendliness and thermal and water stability of materials are requisites for applications. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) were used to inspect the thermal stability of HPU-13 (Figure S1a,b). The TGA analysis shows that HPU-13 loses weight from 70 to 102 °C, ascribed to the free CH3CH2OH and H2O molecules (calcd 19.4% H2O and 9.9% CH3CH2OH), and the framework starts to collapse at 378 °C. The PXRD of synthesized HPU-13, which is similar to the simulated result from the single-crystal data, reveals the purity of HPU-13. In addition, the PXRD patterns of a fresh sample of HPU-13 in H2O for 72 h also matches well with that of the original synthesized product, proving that this material has a good resistance to H2O. Therefore, such H2O stability makes HPU-13 more feasible in practical applications.

elements.content: The SEM images clearly showed the Fe3O4 nanoparticle coated onto the long rodlike crystals of HPU-13 (). The distribution of Fe, Cu, and O contained in the products was also characterized by elemental mapping (). The PXRD patterns of Fe3O4 and HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 are both presented in a. The primary diffraction peaks of the magnetite-loaded HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 are analogous to those of HPU-13, which indicates that the crystal phases of HPU-13 were well maintained after the hybridization with Fe3O4. b provides the IR spectra of Fe3O4, HPU-13, and Fe 3 O 4 @HPU-13. Fe 3 O 4 @HPU-13 not only retained the IR spectrum of HPU-13 but also has the main IR peaks of Fe3O4. The evidence above provided support for the successful synthesis of an Fe 3 O 4 @HPU-13 hybrid material made up of Fe3O4 and HPU-13.
elements.clean_text:
Hybridization of HPU-13 and Fe3O4 

The SEM images clearly showed the Fe3O4 nanoparticle coated onto the long rodlike crystals of HPU-13 (). The distribution of Fe, Cu, and O contained in the products was also characterized by elemental mapping (). The PXRD patterns of Fe3O4 and HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  are both presented in a. The primary diffraction peaks of the magnetite-loaded HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  are analogous to those of HPU-13, which indicates that the crystal phases of HPU-13 were well maintained after the hybridization with Fe3O4. b provides the IR spectra of Fe3O4, HPU-13, and Fe  3  O  4  @HPU-13. Fe  3  O  4  @HPU-13 not only retained the IR spectrum of HPU-13 but also has the main IR peaks of Fe3O4. The evidence above provided support for the successful synthesis of an Fe  3  O  4  @HPU-13 hybrid material made up of Fe3O4 and HPU-13.

elements.content: The performance of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 for the removal of Cr­(VI) from water was explored. The intensity of the characteristic adsorption peaks of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– decreased to a great extent within only 60 min, as shown in . The adsorption effect of Cr­(VI) by Fe3O4 is also provided in , which shows that Fe3O4 has almost no adsorption. This means that HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 synthesized from the selective raw material could be used for future research of Cr­(VI) removal.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of Adsorption Performance

The performance of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  for the removal of Cr(VI) from water was explored. The intensity of the characteristic adsorption peaks of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- decreased to a great extent within only 60 min, as shown in . The adsorption effect of Cr(VI) by Fe3O4 is also provided in , which shows that Fe3O4 has almost no adsorption. This means that HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  synthesized from the selective raw material could be used for future research of Cr(VI) removal.

elements.content: Adsorption of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– by Fe3O4 and HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 (20 mg of adsorbents, 100 mg/L, 10 mL of Cr­(VI)).
elements.clean_text: 5  Adsorption of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- by Fe3O4 and HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  (20 mg of adsorbents, 100 mg/L, 10 mL of Cr(VI)).

elements.content: The Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– adsorption capacities are a vital aspect of the sorbent performance metrics. The q e versus C e plots at 25 °C are shown in a and a. The experimental results were fitted by using Langmuir models, which are shown by the equation C e q e = C e q m + 1 q m K L where q e and q m represent the Cr­(VI) adsorption capacity of material at equilibrium and the maximum amount of Cr­(VI) occupying the surface or pores of the material (mg/g), respectively, and C e and K L denote the equilibrium Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– concentration (mg/L) and Langmuir adsorption constant, respectively. The fitting results indicated that the experimental data matched well with the Langmuir model (R 2 = 0.98643, 0.99656). The maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– adsorbed on HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 were 398.41 and 471.69 mg/g, respectively, which are larger than those for most of the reported cationic MOFs used in Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– adsorption (Tables S2 and S3). This suggests that HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 can be efficiently applied in purifying a Cr­(VI)-polluted system. In addition, the maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– adsorbed on HPU-13 were 431.65 and 495.12 mg/g, respectively, which are slightly more than those of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 . The greater adsorption capacity is due to the larger BET surface area of HPU-13. When HPU-13 is hybridized by Fe3O4, the BET surface area of HPU-13 is reduced to an extent.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorptive Kinetics and Adsorptive Isotherms

The Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- adsorption capacities are a vital aspect of the sorbent performance metrics. The q e versus C e plots at 25 °C are shown in a and a. The experimental results were fitted by using Langmuir models, which are shown by the equation         C   e       q   e     =     C   e       q   m     +   1     q   m     K   L       where q e and q m represent the Cr(VI) adsorption capacity of material at equilibrium and the maximum amount of Cr(VI) occupying the surface or pores of the material (mg/g), respectively, and C e and K L denote the equilibrium Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- concentration (mg/L) and Langmuir adsorption constant, respectively. The fitting results indicated that the experimental data matched well with the Langmuir model (R 2 = 0.98643, 0.99656). The maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- adsorbed on HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  were 398.41 and 471.69 mg/g, respectively, which are larger than those for most of the reported cationic MOFs used in Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- adsorption (Tables S2 and S3). This suggests that HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  can be efficiently applied in purifying a Cr(VI)-polluted system. In addition, the maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- adsorbed on HPU-13 were 431.65 and 495.12 mg/g, respectively, which are slightly more than those of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 . The greater adsorption capacity is due to the larger BET surface area of HPU-13. When HPU-13 is hybridized by Fe3O4, the BET surface area of HPU-13 is reduced to an extent.

(c) Adsorption isotherms for K2Cr2O7 adsorption over HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 . (d) Plots of pseudo-second-order kinetics for the adsorption of K2Cr2O7 on HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 .

elements.content: b and b show the dependence of the amount of Cr­(VI) adsorption by HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 on increasing time. In the beginning, the adsorption capability of Cr­(VI) by HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 increased rapidly. To obtain the adsorption rate constants, a pseudo-second-order model was introduced to fit the experimental data; the model is showed as t q t = t q e + 1 k 2 q e 2 where q t, q e, and k 2 stand for the adsorption capacity at time t, the adsorption capacity at equilibrium, and the pseudo-second-order model rate constant, respectively. The pseudo-second-order kinetic curves are also shown in b and b, which indicate that the experimental data could be evaluated well to the pseudo-second-order model with appropriate correlation coefficients (R 2 > 0.97) (Table S4). Moreover, the q e values match well with the experimental data. The experimental facts manifest that the adsorption behavior of Cr­(VI) by HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is chemical adsorption.
elements.clean_text: b and b show the dependence of the amount of Cr(VI) adsorption by HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  on increasing time. In the beginning, the adsorption capability of Cr(VI) by HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  increased rapidly. To obtain the adsorption rate constants, a pseudo-second-order model was introduced to fit the experimental data; the model is showed as       t     q   t     =   t     q   e     +   1     k   2     q   e   2       where q t, q e, and k 2 stand for the adsorption capacity at time t, the adsorption capacity at equilibrium, and the pseudo-second-order model rate constant, respectively. The pseudo-second-order kinetic curves are also shown in b and b, which indicate that the experimental data could be evaluated well to the pseudo-second-order model with appropriate correlation coefficients (R 2 > 0.97) (Table S4). Moreover, the q e values match well with the experimental data. The experimental facts manifest that the adsorption behavior of Cr(VI) by HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is chemical adsorption.

elements.content: Selective research is also essential to evaluate the efficiency of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 in Cr­(VI) removal. Some anions such as Cl–, H2PO4 –, Br–, SO4 2–, and NO3 – exist in water and also have high affinity for sorbents. Therefore, the selectivity of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 was carried out under the disturbance of the most familiar competing anions: i.e., F–, NO3 –, SO4 2–, Cl–, H2PO4 –, and Br–. As shown in Figure S2, Cr2O7 2– or CrO4 2– was almost totally removed even when 12-fold molar amount of disturbing anions (F–, NO3 –, Cl–, H2PO4 –, Br–, and SO4 2–) existed in the same environment, revealing the excellent selectivity of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 toward Cr­(VI).
elements.clean_text:
Effects of the Competing Ions

Selective research is also essential to evaluate the efficiency of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  in Cr(VI) removal. Some anions such as Cl-, H2PO4 -, Br-, SO4 2-, and NO3 - exist in water and also have high affinity for sorbents. Therefore, the selectivity of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  was carried out under the disturbance of the most familiar competing anions: i.e., F-, NO3 -, SO4 2-, Cl-, H2PO4 -, and Br-. As shown in Figure S2, Cr2O7 2- or CrO4 2- was almost totally removed even when 12-fold molar amount of disturbing anions (F-, NO3 -, Cl-, H2PO4 -, Br-, and SO4 2-) existed in the same environment, revealing the excellent selectivity of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  toward Cr(VI).

elements.content: The reusability of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is also required for practical use (). The cycling experiment was carried out by soaking the Cr­(VI)-loaded products in NaNO3-saturated aqueous solution. After 2 h, almost all of the Cr­(VI) was washed out. The adsorption and desorption processes were performed for 6 cycles. The adsorption capacity was almost unchanged. It is notable that the PXRD pattern never changed from the first adsorption to the sixth adsorption, indicating the recyclability and reversibility of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 in purifying Cr­(VI)-polluted water.
elements.clean_text:
Cycle Experiment

The reusability of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is also required for practical use (). The cycling experiment was carried out by soaking the Cr(VI)-loaded products in NaNO3-saturated aqueous solution. After 2 h, almost all of the Cr(VI) was washed out. The adsorption and desorption processes were performed for 6 cycles. The adsorption capacity was almost unchanged. It is notable that the PXRD pattern never changed from the first adsorption to the sixth adsorption, indicating the recyclability and reversibility of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  in purifying Cr(VI)-polluted water.

elements.content: Cycle experiment of Cr­(VI) adsorption.
elements.clean_text: 8  Cycle experiment of Cr(VI) adsorption.

elements.content: As Cu­(I) ions exist in HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 , a redox reaction would can happen when HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is in contact with Cr­(VI). In our case, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to explain the adsorption mechanism. a shows that there is only Cu­(I) in HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 . For HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 ∩Cr­(VI) after 1 cycle, the peaks deconvoluted into two doublets belonging to Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 (b). The pattern made up of two peaks has binding energies of 942.42 and 962.23 eV ascribed to Cu­(II); the other pattern with binding energies of 932.17 and 951.98 eV corresponds to that of Cu­(I), suggesting that the partial oxidation of Cu­(I) to Cu­(II) on the HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 particles occurred during the adsorption. In addition, we also tested the chemical status of Cr on the surface of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 (b). From the results, the main presence of Cr­(III) was supported by a high-resolution XPS spectrum of the Cr 2p region. In this situation, the adsorption for Cr­(VI) on HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is mainly attributed to the reducibility of Cu+. The low-valent Cu­(I) has a high affinity toward Cr2O7 2– so as to work as efficient adsorptive sites for Cr­(VI). XPS measurements were also performed on the HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 ∩Cr­(VI) products after 5 cycles, which confirmed the main existence of Cu­(II) (c). Almost all of the Cu­(I) is oxidized to Cu­(II). In addition, there is a large amount of Cr­(VI) and relatively little Cr­(III) in the products. Furthermore, the absorption capacity of Cr­(VI) by HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is almost unchanged. Therefore, the powerful hierarchical pore structure of HPU-13 permits the diffusion of Cr­(VI) into the interior of the crystal, which takes a dominant position for the high Cr­(VI) removal in this cycle. Therefore, the adsorption of Cr­(VI) by HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is not just a single process but contains two steps as follows: (1) the adsorbed Cr­(VI) is partially reduced by adsorbents because of the reducibility of Cu­(I) and (2) the large cationic channel cab afford active sites for Cr­(VI), which are the keys to achieve high Cr­(VI) accessibility.
elements.clean_text:
Plausible Adsorption Mechanism

As Cu(I) ions exist in HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 , a redox reaction would can happen when HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is in contact with Cr(VI). In our case, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to explain the adsorption mechanism. a shows that there is only Cu(I) in HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 . For HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 ∩Cr(VI) after 1 cycle, the peaks deconvoluted into two doublets belonging to Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 (b). The pattern made up of two peaks has binding energies of 942.42 and 962.23 eV ascribed to Cu(II); the other pattern with binding energies of 932.17 and 951.98 eV corresponds to that of Cu(I), suggesting that the partial oxidation of Cu(I) to Cu(II) on the HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  particles occurred during the adsorption. In addition, we also tested the chemical status of Cr on the surface of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  (b). From the results, the main presence of Cr(III) was supported by a high-resolution XPS spectrum of the Cr 2p region. In this situation, the adsorption for Cr(VI) on HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is mainly attributed to the reducibility of Cu+. The low-valent Cu(I) has a high affinity toward Cr2O7 2- so as to work as efficient adsorptive sites for Cr(VI). XPS measurements were also performed on the HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 ∩Cr(VI) products after 5 cycles, which confirmed the main existence of Cu(II) (c). Almost all of the Cu(I) is oxidized to Cu(II). In addition, there is a large amount of Cr(VI) and relatively little Cr(III) in the products. Furthermore, the absorption capacity of Cr(VI) by HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is almost unchanged. Therefore, the powerful hierarchical pore structure of HPU-13 permits the diffusion of Cr(VI) into the interior of the crystal, which takes a dominant position for the high Cr(VI) removal in this cycle. Therefore, the adsorption of Cr(VI) by HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is not just a single process but contains two steps as follows: (1) the adsorbed Cr(VI) is partially reduced by adsorbents because of the reducibility of Cu(I) and (2) the large cationic channel cab afford active sites for Cr(VI), which are the keys to achieve high Cr(VI) accessibility.

elements.content: XPS spectra of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 before and after adsorption: (a) Cu 2p before adsorption; (b) Cu 2p and Cr 2p after adsorption for one cycle; (c) Cu 2p and Cr 2p after adsorption for 6 cycles.
elements.clean_text: 9  XPS spectra of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  before and after adsorption: (a) Cu 2p before adsorption; (b) Cu 2p and Cr 2p after adsorption for one cycle; (c) Cu 2p and Cr 2p after adsorption for 6 cycles.

elements.content: To further prove our presumption, the adsorption of anionic dyes from the mixed dyes was studied. From Figure S3, the absorption of MO (methyl orange) disappeared while the absorption of other cationic dyes was almost unchanged, which suggested that HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 could selectively adsorb anionic molecules MO. The selective adsorption of MO may result from the electrostatic interaction of the anionic MO molecules and cationic framework of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 . In addition, we also studied the separation of different anionic dyes (MO, NGB (Naphthol Green B), and AYR (Alizarin yellow R)) from AYR&MO, AYR&NGB, and NGB&MO (Figure S4). The results indicated that the adsorption of AYR by HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is better than that of other anionic dyes, which may be ascribed to the smaller size of AYR molecules. PXRD confirmed that the crystalline integrity of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 was retained during dye adsorption (Figure S5). The overall adsorption capacities of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 for MO and AYR reaches up to 76.336 and 163.399 mg g–1, respectively ( and Figures S6 and S7 and Tables S5–S7). In addition, the adsorption–release cycle experiments showed that this material still has the same high removal efficiency toward AYR (Figure S8). Furthermore, PXRD patterns of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 after four cycles are consistent with those of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 , which indicates the framework integrity of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is well retained (Figure S6). This demonstrates that the hierarchical pore structure is also a key to achieving Cr­(VI) or dye removal.
elements.clean_text: To further prove our presumption, the adsorption of anionic dyes from the mixed dyes was studied. From Figure S3, the absorption of MO (methyl orange) disappeared while the absorption of other cationic dyes was almost unchanged, which suggested that HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  could selectively adsorb anionic molecules MO. The selective adsorption of MO may result from the electrostatic interaction of the anionic MO molecules and cationic framework of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 . In addition, we also studied the separation of different anionic dyes (MO, NGB (Naphthol Green B), and AYR (Alizarin yellow R)) from AYR&MO, AYR&NGB, and NGB&MO (Figure S4). The results indicated that the adsorption of AYR by HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is better than that of other anionic dyes, which may be ascribed to the smaller size of AYR molecules. PXRD confirmed that the crystalline integrity of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  was retained during dye adsorption (Figure S5). The overall adsorption capacities of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  for MO and AYR reaches up to 76.336 and 163.399 mg g-1, respectively ( and Figures S6 and S7 and Tables S5-S7). In addition, the adsorption-release cycle experiments showed that this material still has the same high removal efficiency toward AYR (Figure S8). Furthermore, PXRD patterns of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  after four cycles are consistent with those of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 , which indicates the framework integrity of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is well retained (Figure S6). This demonstrates that the hierarchical pore structure is also a key to achieving Cr(VI) or dye removal.

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms for MO and AYR adsorption over HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 .
elements.clean_text: 10  Adsorption isotherms for MO and AYR adsorption over HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 .

elements.content: In summary, the original magnetic HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 hybrid with excellent reusable Cr­(VI) adsorption capability was introduced in our work. The maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– adsorbed on HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 were 398.41 and 471.69 mg/g, respectively, which are greater than those of the reported cationic MOFs used in Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 – adsorption. Adsorption mechanism studies confirmed that the synergistic reaction of Cr­(VI) reduction and adsorption gave rise to the high Cr­(VI) removal efficiency. Our data presented the magnetic hybrid HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 , which could be used as a functional, practical, and effective adsorbent for treating wastewater that includes Cr­(VI).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the original magnetic HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  hybrid with excellent reusable Cr(VI) adsorption capability was introduced in our work. The maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- adsorbed on HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  were 398.41 and 471.69 mg/g, respectively, which are greater than those of the reported cationic MOFs used in Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 - adsorption. Adsorption mechanism studies confirmed that the synergistic reaction of Cr(VI) reduction and adsorption gave rise to the high Cr(VI) removal efficiency. Our data presented the magnetic hybrid HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 , which could be used as a functional, practical, and effective adsorbent for treating wastewater that includes Cr(VI).

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of CuSO4 (24.9 mg) and HL (11 mg) in H2O and ethanol (8/2) was placed in a 15 mL bottle and heated for 72 h at 160 °C. The final solution was cooled to room temperature, and then yellow block crystals of HPU-13 were acquired, washed with acetone, and dried in air. Yield: 78%. Anal. Calcd for C26H47Cu3N12O13: C, 33.71; H, 5.11; N, 18.14. Found: C, 33.64; H, 5.16; N, 18.22.

Preparation of Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> Particles

The Fe3O4 particles were prepared according to the literature.

Synthesis of Magnetic <bold>HPU-13@Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> </bold> particles

A mixture of CuSO4 (24.9 mg) and HL (11 mg) in H2O and ethanol (8/2) was first stirred for 30 min. Then, to the solution was added 2 mg of Fe3O4, and this mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon liner and heated to 160 °C for 72 h. The final product was centrifuged and washed several times with fresh water.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Cu3(L)2]⋅OH⋅2CH3CH2OH⋅10H2O} n  (HPU-13)

A mixture of CuSO4 (24.9 mg) and HL (11 mg) in H2O and ethanol (8/2) was placed in a 15 mL bottle and heated for 72 h at 160 °C. The final solution was cooled to room temperature, and then yellow block crystals of HPU-13 were acquired, washed with acetone, and dried in air. Yield: 78%. Anal. Calcd for C26H47Cu3N12O13: C, 33.71; H, 5.11; N, 18.14. Found: C, 33.64; H, 5.16; N, 18.22.

Preparation of Fe3O4 Particles

The Fe3O4 particles were prepared according to the literature. 

Synthesis of Magnetic HPU-13@Fe3O4  particles

A mixture of CuSO4 (24.9 mg) and HL (11 mg) in H2O and ethanol (8/2) was first stirred for 30 min. Then, to the solution was added 2 mg of Fe3O4, and this mixture was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon liner and heated to 160 °C for 72 h. The final product was centrifuged and washed several times with fresh water.

cln_elements.content:
It is an urgent topic for public health and environmental protection to remove Cr­(VI) from wastewater effectively and conveniently. Herein, we fabricate the novel hybrid magnetic material HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 (HPU-13 = {[Cu3(L)2]·OH·2CH3CH2OH·10H2O} n ; HL = 2-(5-pyridin-4-yl-2H-[1,2,4]­triazol-3-yl)­pyrimidine), which shows excellent Cr­(VI) removal efficiency and is easily employed as a reusable absorbent. The maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– adsorbed on HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 were 398.41 and 471.69 mg/g, respectively, larger than those of reported MOFs used in Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– adsorption. Adsorption mechanism studies confirmed that the synergistic reaction of Cr­(VI) reduction and adsorption was responsible for the high removal efficiency. The above evidence proved that HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 has the potential functional ability to decontaminate Cr­(VI) polluted water systems.

Results and DiscussionStructural Description

HPU-13 crystallizes in the rrigonal system with space group P3̅c1, which is clearly indicated by single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis. It consists of hexagonal and triangular cationic micropores with a three-dimensional crystallographically imposed molecular symmetry. As depicted in a, the ligand has a μ4-bridging mode with each of the ligand’s six nitrogen atoms linking with four Cu­(I) ions by all of the nitrogen atoms. The two crystallographically independent Cu­(I) atoms possess distorted-tetrahedral geometries. Three independent ligands bridge six Cu­(I) atoms to form a closed triangular unit, which link with another triangular unit in a face-to-face direction, giving rise to a closed cage (b,c). Four adjacent triangular cages are connected together to form a hexagonal mesropore. An investigation of the crystal packing indicates that HPU-13 shows a porous structural character with two different channels: hexagonal and triangular micropores along the c axis due to the existence of the skeletons of ligands. The hexagonal cage has large dimensions of 20.947 × 20.720 Å2 (d,e). The triangular micropores have a pore size of 4 Å from the nitrogen atoms of HL groups. Finally, the whole structure might appear as an expansion of the MIL-68 structure (f). The effective free voids of HPU-13 are occupied as 36.0% of the crystal volume, which was calculated by PLATON analysis (1728.9 out of 4803.0 Å3, the unit cell volume).

Thermal and Water Stability Tests

The eco-friendliness and thermal and water stability of materials are requisites for applications. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) were used to inspect the thermal stability of HPU-13 (Figure S1a,b). The TGA analysis shows that HPU-13 loses weight from 70 to 102 °C, ascribed to the free CH3CH2OH and H2O molecules (calcd 19.4% H2O and 9.9% CH3CH2OH), and the framework starts to collapse at 378 °C. The PXRD of synthesized HPU-13, which is similar to the simulated result from the single-crystal data, reveals the purity of HPU-13. In addition, the PXRD patterns of a fresh sample of HPU-13 in H2O for 72 h also matches well with that of the original synthesized product, proving that this material has a good resistance to H2O. Therefore, such H2O stability makes HPU-13 more feasible in practical applications.

To further prove our presumption, the adsorption of anionic dyes from the mixed dyes was studied. From Figure S3, the absorption of MO (methyl orange) disappeared while the absorption of other cationic dyes was almost unchanged, which suggested that HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 could selectively adsorb anionic molecules MO. The selective adsorption of MO may result from the electrostatic interaction of the anionic MO molecules and cationic framework of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 . In addition, we also studied the separation of different anionic dyes (MO, NGB (Naphthol Green B), and AYR (Alizarin yellow R)) from AYR&MO, AYR&NGB, and NGB&MO (Figure S4). The results indicated that the adsorption of AYR by HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is better than that of other anionic dyes, which may be ascribed to the smaller size of AYR molecules. PXRD confirmed that the crystalline integrity of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 was retained during dye adsorption (Figure S5). The overall adsorption capacities of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 for MO and AYR reaches up to 76.336 and 163.399 mg g–1, respectively ( and Figures S6 and S7 and Tables S5–S7). In addition, the adsorption–release cycle experiments showed that this material still has the same high removal efficiency toward AYR (Figure S8). Furthermore, PXRD patterns of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 after four cycles are consistent with those of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 , which indicates the framework integrity of HPU-13@Fe 3 O 4 is well retained (Figure S6). This demonstrates that the hierarchical pore structure is also a key to achieving Cr­(VI) or dye removal.
cln_elements.clean_text:
It is an urgent topic for public health and environmental protection to remove Cr(VI) from wastewater effectively and conveniently. Herein, we fabricate the novel hybrid magnetic material HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  (HPU-13 = {[Cu3(L)2]⋅OH⋅2CH3CH2OH⋅10H2O} n ; HL = 2-(5-pyridin-4-yl-2H-[1,2,4]triazol-3-yl)pyrimidine), which shows excellent Cr(VI) removal efficiency and is easily employed as a reusable absorbent. The maximum capacities of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- adsorbed on HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  were 398.41 and 471.69 mg/g, respectively, larger than those of reported MOFs used in Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- adsorption. Adsorption mechanism studies confirmed that the synergistic reaction of Cr(VI) reduction and adsorption was responsible for the high removal efficiency. The above evidence proved that HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  has the potential functional ability to decontaminate Cr(VI) polluted water systems.

Results and Discussion

Structural Description

 HPU-13 crystallizes in the rrigonal system with space group P3̅c1, which is clearly indicated by single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis. It consists of hexagonal and triangular cationic micropores with a three-dimensional crystallographically imposed molecular symmetry. As depicted in a, the ligand has a μ4-bridging mode with each of the ligand's six nitrogen atoms linking with four Cu(I) ions by all of the nitrogen atoms. The two crystallographically independent Cu(I) atoms possess distorted-tetrahedral geometries. Three independent ligands bridge six Cu(I) atoms to form a closed triangular unit, which link with another triangular unit in a face-to-face direction, giving rise to a closed cage (b,c). Four adjacent triangular cages are connected together to form a hexagonal mesropore. An investigation of the crystal packing indicates that HPU-13 shows a porous structural character with two different channels: hexagonal and triangular micropores along the c axis due to the existence of the skeletons of ligands. The hexagonal cage has large dimensions of 20.947 × 20.720 Å2 (d,e). The triangular micropores have a pore size of 4 Å from the nitrogen atoms of HL groups. Finally, the whole structure might appear as an expansion of the MIL-68 structure (f). The effective free voids of HPU-13 are occupied as 36.0% of the crystal volume, which was calculated by PLATON analysis (1728.9 out of 4803.0 Å3, the unit cell volume).

Thermal and Water Stability Tests

The eco-friendliness and thermal and water stability of materials are requisites for applications. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) were used to inspect the thermal stability of HPU-13 (Figure S1a,b). The TGA analysis shows that HPU-13 loses weight from 70 to 102 °C, ascribed to the free CH3CH2OH and H2O molecules (calcd 19.4% H2O and 9.9% CH3CH2OH), and the framework starts to collapse at 378 °C. The PXRD of synthesized HPU-13, which is similar to the simulated result from the single-crystal data, reveals the purity of HPU-13. In addition, the PXRD patterns of a fresh sample of HPU-13 in H2O for 72 h also matches well with that of the original synthesized product, proving that this material has a good resistance to H2O. Therefore, such H2O stability makes HPU-13 more feasible in practical applications.

To further prove our presumption, the adsorption of anionic dyes from the mixed dyes was studied. From Figure S3, the absorption of MO (methyl orange) disappeared while the absorption of other cationic dyes was almost unchanged, which suggested that HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  could selectively adsorb anionic molecules MO. The selective adsorption of MO may result from the electrostatic interaction of the anionic MO molecules and cationic framework of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 . In addition, we also studied the separation of different anionic dyes (MO, NGB (Naphthol Green B), and AYR (Alizarin yellow R)) from AYR&MO, AYR&NGB, and NGB&MO (Figure S4). The results indicated that the adsorption of AYR by HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is better than that of other anionic dyes, which may be ascribed to the smaller size of AYR molecules. PXRD confirmed that the crystalline integrity of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  was retained during dye adsorption (Figure S5). The overall adsorption capacities of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  for MO and AYR reaches up to 76.336 and 163.399 mg g-1, respectively ( and Figures S6 and S7 and Tables S5-S7). In addition, the adsorption-release cycle experiments showed that this material still has the same high removal efficiency toward AYR (Figure S8). Furthermore, PXRD patterns of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  after four cycles are consistent with those of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4 , which indicates the framework integrity of HPU-13@Fe  3  O  4  is well retained (Figure S6). This demonstrates that the hierarchical pore structure is also a key to achieving Cr(VI) or dye removal.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Schematics of Adsorption of Cr­(VI) by <bold>HPU-13@Fe</bold>

metadata.title:
The Magnetic Hybrid Cu(I)-MOF@Fe3O4 with Hierarchically Engineered Micropores for Highly Efficient
